Bake Off Data!

Author

Ricky Case

Published

February 12, 2023

Introduction

In this data visualization project, I will be using a attempting to determine whether there is a correlation between a contestantâ€™s ability to win Technical Challenges and their likelihood of winning the series.

This data was retrieved from the GitHub repository Bakeoff.

Libraries Included

library(tidyverse)

Preparing The Data

I began by playing around with the data, seeing what parsed out sub-sets might be best-suited to my examination.
There are what I ended up deciding to go with.

The Useful Data

This Dataset is a narrowed-down version of the original, listing only relevant data.

bakers |>
    select(series, baker, series_winner, technical_winner) ->
    bakerData

bakerData
# A tibble: 120 Ã— 4
   series baker     series_winner technical_winner
    <dbl> <chr>             <int>            <int>
 1      1 Annetha               0                0
 2      1 David                 0                0
 3      1 Edd                   1                2
 4      1 Jasminder             0                0
 5      1 Jonathan              0                1
 6      1 Lea                   0                0
 7      1 Louise                0                0
 8      1 Mark                  0                0
 9      1 Miranda               0                2
10      1 Ruth                  0                0
# â€¦ with 110 more rows

The Top Performers

From there, I created a new Data Sub-Set in order to further categorize the relevant data.

bakerData |>
    filter(technical_winner >= 3) ->
    topPerformers

topPerformers
# A tibble: 7 Ã— 4
  series baker     series_winner technical_winner
   <dbl> <chr>             <int>            <int>
1      2 Joanne                1                3
2      3 James                 0                5
3      4 Kimberley             0                3
4      5 Nancy                 1                3
5      6 Nadiya                1                4
6      8 Steven                0                3
7      9 Ruby                  0                3

Making The Graph

Initially I wasnâ€™t sure which type of graph would be illustrate the data, though I eventually settled on a bar graph. 

ggplot(
    topPerformers,
    aes(baker, technical_winner)) + 
geom_col()

Side-By-Side

I then attempted using the ggplot2 facet_wrap() function to create a side-by side look at top performers, comparing those who won with those who lost. 

ggplot(
    topPerformers,
    aes(baker, technical_winner)) + 
geom_col() +
facet_wrap(~series_winner)

Unhappy with the gaps created by the inclusion of ever baker on both parts, I becided to find a way to display two separate graphs side-by-side.

topPerformers |>
    filter(series_winner == 0) ->
    topPerformersWhoLost

topPerformers |>
    filter(series_winner == 1) ->
    topPerformersWhoWon

grid.arrange(
    ggplot(
        topPerformersWhoLost,
        aes(baker, technical_winner)) +
    geom_col(),
    
    ggplot(
        topPerformersWhoWon,
        aes(baker, technical_winner)) +
    geom_col(),
    
    ncol = 2
)

Clearly, this is better but itâ€™s also difficult to understand. Specifically, how is anyone to understand whatâ€™s different between the two lists of bakers? Now it was time to edit the label text to fix this.

Editing the labeling

grid.arrange(
    ggplot(
        topPerformersWhoLost,
        aes(baker, technical_winner)) +
    geom_col() +
    xlab("Losers") +
    ylab("Technical Wins"),
    
    ggplot(
        topPerformersWhoWon,
        aes(baker, technical_winner)) +
    geom_col() +
    xlab("Winners") +
    ylab(""),
    
    ncol = 2
)

Now, with the label text sorted out, I needed to make it stand out a bit more. 

grid.arrange(
    ggplot(
        topPerformersWhoLost,
        aes(baker, technical_winner)) +
    geom_col() +
    xlab("Losers") +
    ylab("Technical Wins") +
    theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 16, family = "Arial")),
    
    ggplot(
        topPerformersWhoWon,
        aes(baker, technical_winner)) +
    geom_col() +
    xlab("Winners") +
    ylab("") +
    theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 16, family = "Arial")),
    
    ncol = 2
)

At this point, it became apparent that the current scales of these graphs were a bit misleading.With the graph on the right having a y-axis sxale ending with a value of 4, 4 wins on this graph appeared equivilent to the value of 5 wins on the left graph.
This needed to be fixedâ€¦ 

grid.arrange(
    ggplot(
        topPerformersWhoLost,
        aes(baker, technical_winner)) +
    geom_col() +
    xlab("Losers") +
    ylab("Technical Wins") +
    theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 16, family = "Arial")),
    
    ggplot(
        topPerformersWhoWon,
        aes(baker, technical_winner)) +
    geom_col() +
    xlab("Winners") +
    ylab("") +
    theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 16, family = "Arial")) +
    scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 5)),
    
    ncol = 2
)

Finally, with my data arranged correctly on these two graphs, it was time to make it all a bit prettier to look at.

I decided to go with a white background and blue columns, becasue itâ€™s simple and easy to read. 

grid.arrange(
    ggplot(
        topPerformersWhoLost,
        aes(baker, technical_winner)) +
    geom_col(width = 0.9, fill = "blue") +
    xlab("Losers") +
    ylab("Technical Wins") +
    theme(
        axis.title = element_text(size = 16, family = "Arial"),
        plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
        panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white")
    ),
    
    ggplot(
        topPerformersWhoWon,
        aes(baker, technical_winner)) +
    geom_col(width = 0.9, fill = "blue") +
    xlab("Winners") +
    ylab("") +
    theme(
        axis.title = element_text(size = 16, family = "Arial"),
        plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
        panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white")
    ) +
    scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 5)),
    
    ncol = 2
)

Interestingly, I expected to be able to draw some kind of correlation between technical wins and a bakerâ€™s liklihood of winning the series. However, this data appears to show that no correlation exists at all! Not that I think thatâ€™s necessarily important. Though I do find it very interesting!

Perhaps the takeaway is that the technicals arenâ€™t actually very important? For someone with the time and interest, this might be an interesting question to try and answer.
